wikipedia_page.main: Kate Russell (born c. 1968) is an English technology journalist, author, speaker, gamer and streamer.

response: The programme previously included Webscape, a closing segment hosted by Kate Russell recommending new and useful websites. This segment was dropped but Russell continued doing general reporting for the show.
In addition to presenters Kelly and Lewington, reporters include Dan Simmons, Omar Mehtab, LJ Rich, Paul Carter, Jen Copestake, Marc Cieslak, Nick Kwek, Chris Fox, Sumi Das and Kate Russell.

* Chips with Everything - 20-minute weekday show presented by Kate Russell with guests trying to answer computer-related questions that were sent in by viewers. Guests included: Roger Gann, James Morris, Simon Smart, Nigel Whitfield, Guy Clapperton, and Charles Bocock.

response: *Kate Russell (reporter) (Kathryn Jane Russell, born 1968), British reporter
In 2011, Bookboon was featured in BBC News' Webscape segment technology show Click presented by Kate Russell.[4]
Kate Russell of the BBC reported on the company's products in August 2012.

In 2012, the updated web page with Incredibox 2.0 (later known as Little Miss) became instantly popular, that, after 600,000 visits in one day, the server crashed on April 13. During this week, the word "Incredibox" was the search term with "the most significant growth worldwide", as measured by Google Insights. At that time the success was partly due to the fact that several media like Vice, Jayisgames or Kotaku enjoyed the "simple" and "fun" concept of Incredibox, while others praised the innovative and creative approach of the interface: Slate's Forrest Wickman wrote that Incredibox was "wonderfully surreal", and in the meantime on Gizmodo Eliot Van Buskirk said that "as a demonstration of outside the box thinking about how to promote a song, Incredibox is impressive". During the BBC technology show Click on November 17, 2012, Kate Russell described Incredibox as a "brilliant browser sequencer" and explained that users "don’t need to be a musical genius, as it’s pretty much impossible to make something that sounds bad".
